Ireland AwardsIT AwardsProperty AwardsPet ExpoDownNorthern IrelandNews HeadlinesBelfasttelegraphNews [] Opinion [] Business [] Sport [] Le [] Entertainment [] Travel [] Sunday Le [] SearchSearchMenuSections #fp-snackbar #fp-snackbar.fp-show ClosePremium Northern Ireland power station wants to ditch Russian coal — but Stormont says noSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : PMFacebookTwitterEmailOne of Northern Ireland’s main power stations wants to stop buying Russian coal — but is forced to do so by Stormont’s licence requirements.A huge shipment of Russian coal arrived in Belfast Harbour at the weekend using a vessel registered in the Marshall Islands to transport the consignment to Belfast Harbour, meaning it was landed without breaking the UK’s sanctions regime.On Tuesday much of the shipment was still visible in the harbour. Kilroot power station said that shipment was not for it, and it last brought in Russian coal on th February. The power station, which dominates the northern shoreline of Belfast Lough just east of Carrickfergus, is our last coal-fired electricity generation plant and is due to close next year.Read MoreUkrainian refugee scheme: Vital that sponsors in Northern Ireland are properly checked, warns anti-slavery expertUp to £m of RHI money may go unspent by StormontHowever, it is still key to keeping the lights on, and has been called upon more in recent years due to problems at other power stations and unusually calm days reducing wind power generation.Coal was Russia’s third most valuable export by value in , bringing in £.bn. Northern Ireland was the only UK region to see coal-fired electricity generation increase that year, accounting for % of all electricity.Energy imports from Russia have not been banned, but have come under scrutiny due to revulsion at Vladimir Putin’s invasion of Ukraine and the escalation of the war through the targeting of civilians.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Kilroot’s position appears similar to that of Shell, which bought Russian oil — entirely legally — days into the Ukraine war, but backtracked under huge public pressure and promised not to do so again.Read MoreMalachi O#Doherty:OpinionMy utility bills now cost £ a week. Pensioners are in big troubleHowever, Kilroot’s situation is complicated by what it says is a requirement in its licence to buy Russian coal for environmental reasons, because it is low-sulphur, and thus somewhat reduces air pollution when burned.!forfort[r].style.e.data["datawrapper-height"][a]+"px"When Stormont’s Department for the Economy, which is responsible for electricity policy, was askedit believed environmental rules should be relaxed to allow Kilroot to burn dirtier coal, it initially washed its hands of the matter, saying: “The department does not have responsibility for environmental rules. This is the responsibility of DAERA Northern Ireland Environment Agency .”That answer came despite the RHI Inquiry recommending Stormont stopped operating in silos and behaved coherently as a single government entity.However, Kilroot’s owner then told the Belfastit had been meeting the department, NIEA, electricity grid operator SONI and the Utility Regulator to discuss this issue since the crisis began. That was put to the Department for the Economy and to Edwin Poots’ Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, which is responsible for NIEA.But there was no response at the time of going to press.EP Kilroot, a subsidiary of Czech company Energetický, which owns the plant, said it “condemns the indefensible aggression and actions by Russia”.It added that it “complies with all UK sanctions and associated regulations in relation to Russia”, and stressed there were “signicant stock levels of coal on the Kilroot site at present”.It said: “We have contingency plans in place for alternative sources of coal supply. “This plan requires changing EP Kilroot’s permit, which currently prevents us from using coals from other countries.“Since the start of the Ukraine crisis, EP Kilroot has chaired a number of roundtable workshops with officials from DfE, NIEA, the Utility Regulator and SONI to urgently address the issues of the current permitting arrangements to enable EP Kilroot to remove its reliance on Russian coal.“If the permitting arrangements are not changed, we believe there will be signicant security of supply risks that SONI will need to manage.”The company claimed there could also be “signicant additional costs” for consumers “depending on the extent to which the coal units are restricted”.When DfE, headed by DUP minister Gordon Lyons, was asked for its view on whether Kilroot should continue to buy Russian coal, the department expressed no preference, and said: “The purchase of coal is a commercial decision taken by EP Kilroot. However, the department will follow the guidance that has been issued by the UK Government in relation to Russian imports.”When asked how much coal stocks were in place at Kilroot, DfE said “this is not a matter for the department”, but SONI would tell itthere was a problem. When asked how much secondary fuel was stored at Kilroot, DfE said that was a matter for the company.SONI said it was “unaware of any immediate risk to coal stock at Kilroot”. It said inspection of fuel stocks was “not a matter for SONI”. It added Kilroot “has a key role to play in the energy transition”, involving the current generators as well as new gas turbines.Belfast Harbour said it was “working closely with shipping agents and relevant partners to implement all of the Government’s legislative sanctions on Russian vessels”, but it would only bar vessels excluded by law, rather than go further.The Utility Regulator said Kilroot was responsible for ensuring it held adequate fuel stocks. It added: “In light of the ongoing situation in Ukraine, we are working with DfE to proactively monitor the situation, and are engaging with EP Kilroot and other key stakeholders on a regular basis about fuel stocks and fuel security arrangements.”Overall imports of coal have generally been falling, but have risen to the point where they are now roughly where they were in , despite the reduction in the use of coal for home-heating and electricity generation.Irish state-owned electricity company ESB said it will not be taking delivery of Russian coal to its Moneypoint power station in Co Clare “for the foreseeable future”. It was reported that members of staff at the River Shannon facility had expressed concerns to management about accepting Russian coal in the current circumstances.On Monday, Andrei Melnichenko, owner title: shock as young derry workers lay bare exploitation by bosses and low pay rates
story: Young workers who contributed to a Derry-based survey have shared their experiences of being exploited by employers.Councillor Gary DonnellyCouncillor Shaun Harkin FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueYoung workers who contributed to a Derry-based survey have shared their experiences of being exploited by employers.Garrett HarganTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailYoung workers who contributed to a Derry Trade Union Councilsurvey have shared their experiences of being exploited by employers at a special meeting of Derry City and Strabane District Council.DTUC chairman Niall McCarroll said the survey did not make for easy reading.Feedback from more than  workers found % do not earn more than the minimum wage % receive only statutory sick pay, and % struggle with bills.Of these, % are on part-time or zero-hours contracts, face harassment at work, and do not have trade union representation.Hospitality worker Grace Ward , referring to a past job rather than the one she currently holds, told councillors: “Working in the hospitality and tourism sector, I was paid £. an hour with no sick pay, protections or holiday pay.Read MoreParents ‘staggered’ to find Derry crèche locked and children refused entry“I was employed through a zero-hours contract with no guaranteed hours, being sent home earlythe sht was quiet.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up “So, even though I have been offered an eight-hour sht, in many cases I only got paid for five or six hours.”She said girls her age were “fed up with basically working for nothing”, and added her teen colleagues use the term “working poor” to describe themselves.Retail worker Cliona Collins said in the past she had worked for £. per hour, which did not make her feel valued.“I felt uncomfortable and pressured to ask customers to buy more and spend more...I was five minutes late I would lose an hour’s pay,” she explained.“The biggest issue for me and my friends who have a part-time job is the amount we get paid. It’s really demoralising.“I also have to get taxis to and from work, which is around a trip fare of £. It takes me three hours at work to pay for my travel with my shts on average being between seven and eight hours.”With the cost-of-living crisis, she said young workers feel they should receive a pay rise and get the top minimum wage hourly rate of £., as they work as hard as someone aged .Unison’s Saoirse Fanning said the survey findings around Covid were particularly concerning.Twenty-five per cent could not self-isolate, % couldn’t afford to, and % said their employer wouldn’t allow it.She added: “We have been fighting for our members to get paid in full while off sick with Covid- or having to isolate.“Some employers were only paying statutory sick pay, even though money was available from the Department for Communities to pay staff in full.” She said the privatisation of services meant front line staff were on “poverty pay and poor terms and conditions”.She called for a social clause to be included in all contracts outsourced to the community sector.Independent councillor Gary Donnelly said what he was hearing was “shocking”, and asked what council could do to assist.Ms Ward said workers doing the same job should receive the same pay rate regardless of age.Mr McCarroll said Derry suffered from deprivation and neglect from ious governments and it can’t be the case that the city progresses on the back of local workers getting paid just over £ an hour without sick pay.He suggested the council look at wage inequalities and exploitation, and that hospitality businesses should make their pay rates known on menus.People Before Profit councillor Shaun Harkin branded wages for teenagers “a disgrace” and said every worker should receive at least the minimum wage.He proposed initiating research to get an accurate assessment of pay scales across the council area. He was told a motion could be brought before the full council.Councillor Derek Hussey, who has been in the hospitality business since , said he was “really shocked” by Grace and Cliona’s revelations.“The figures you’re quoting, I wouldn’t have got away with back when I first started in the business,” he added.“At the weekend I had an event and had to bring in part-time workers. I can assure you that I had to pay well — well over the minimum wage in order to actually get folk to work.”The DUP’s Hilary McClintock said for someone to have to work for three hours to pay travel and to not have guaranteed hours was “exploitation”.Related topicsDerry City and Strabane District CouncilCost of LivingPeople Before ProfitMore On Derry City and Strabane District CouncilNI was title: st patricks day 2022 events and activities across northern ireland this
story: Jumping for joy: A reveller enjoying himself on a St Patrick’s Day parade in Belfast city centre. Credit: PacemakerThe Spring Carnival in Londonderry. Credit: Martin McKeown. InpresspicsThe Paddy’s Day Paddle in Warrenpoint, Co DownChairman of Broughshane  District Community Association, Lexie Scott with Mayor William McCaughey FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueJumping for joy: A reveller enjoying himself on a St Patrick’s Day parade in Belfast city centre. Credit: PacemakerNiamh CampbellTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailIt was around this time two years ago that people across Northern Ireland were beginning to hear more and more about the Covid- virus that was spreading across the globe.The first official case in NI was recorded on February  and soon after, it was announced that St Patrick’s Day events here would be cancelled.Now, with a multitude of activities and festivities confirmed for the first time in three years, many councils and event organisers are seeing this year’s March  as an opportunity to not only commemorate the death of Ireland’s patron saint in the fth century, but to celebrate a renewed sense of freedom and good news across NI.The Belfasthas compiled a list of all the greatest gatherings and goings-on throughout all six counties on the big day itself.Co TyroneFor those looking to experience a truly traditional St Patrick’s Day, the Ulster American Folk Park just outside Omagh will be letting families discover the food, stories, customs and even dancing that would have taken place on March  during the th, th and th centuries.Of course everyone can also join in on the fun and festivities of the Strabane St Patrick’s Day Parade, and there’s plenty more similar events across the county, including music, face painting, Irish dancing and amusements at Dungannon’s Hill of The O’Neill.Read MoreReturn of St Patrick’s Day celebrations after three years set to boost NI’s economyDaily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up For something a bit dferent, you could enjoy a visit to the Wild Atlantic Distillery in Castlederg for their Distillery Tour, where you can hear how they have been inspired by the people and the landscape to create their famous gin, vodka and whiskey.Co ArmaghArmagh city, where St Patrick built his great stone church in AD, making it the centre of the church in Ireland, will be hosting a special Home of Saint Patrick festival, which began on March  and is running right until Saturday, March . It will combine live music, comedy, art, poetry, theatre, film, dance, debate, history and adventure.At .pm on March , the St Patrick’s Day Community Parade will kick off — a celebration of the Irish patron saint, followed by a family-fun afternoon [with free admission] in the Shambles Market until pm.Co DownFancy a Big Paddy Paddle at the Mourne Outdoor Festival  The Le Adventure Centre is inviting people to celebrate St Patrick’s Day in a style similar to that of Patrick when he first arrived locally — by canoe, SUP Board, or kayak — it’s your choice!It’s a self-guided paddle around Castlewellan and tickets are £ per person, which includes all your equipment and support on the day.You can also do something similar in Warrenpoint and begin the day in style on the beautul shoreline of Carlingford Lough with a Family Paddle from . to .am or the Paddy’s Day Paddle  Pints from . to .pm.The second session of the day follows a similar theme to the morning one, but is followed by drinks off the water and is for adults only. Check out Discover Northern Ireland for details on how to buy tickets for any of these activities.Or, visit St Patrick’s actual grave at the cathedral in Downpatrick, followed by an array of free celebrations commencing at noon in the town’s St Patrick’s Square.Co AntrimThe traditional St Patrick’s Day climb of Slemish will see thousandsfor the first time since , with outdoor entertainment in Broughshane village afterwards, including performances from the lively band, Ragaire, the -strong Portglenone Comhaltas Group, more traditional music and dance, street theatre, crafts and face painting.Colin Glen Forest Park is also going mega green for the day with activities including the Black Bull Run and Forest Flyover Zipline sessions from am to pm. In addition, there will be a bouncy castle, face painting, Irish dancing and a special St Patrick’s Gruffalo and Leprechaun Hunt for little ones, who will get to take home their very own Julia Donaldson and Friends book, sticker and certicate.Visit Colin Glen online to book tickets for any of the day’s activities.Co LondonderryDerry City is hosting a Spring Carnival Parade on March  and it aims to feature more than  participants.Guildhall Square will be turned into an incredible live show with animations and local choirs, while Waterloo Place will be filled with traditional Irish musicians, dancers and homegrown delicacies.The Peace Garden in Foyle Street will be transformed into the Colourful Land of the Little People where children can make a wish on the fairy tree and dance until their feet are sore from  to pm.The Spring Carnival Parade will begin at Bishop Street from pm with a mythical theme of ‘Rebirth  Renewal’.Co FermanaghEnniskillen town centre will come alive once again with street entertainment including the best of local talent with music from Roslea CCE featuring Blathnaid, Saoirse and Darragh Rooney, Irish dancers Aoe Rooney and Caitlin Flanagan, and Sophie Armstrong from Erne Highland Dancers.Enniskillen Castle will also be hosting an exciting programme for the whole family with food vendors, market stalls, live music, balloon modelling and a craft fair.Fermanagh and Omagh District Council confirmed that entertainment will continue into the evening “with so much on offer in the wonderful hospitality and entertainment venues across the Island Town on this global day of celebration”.Belfast city centreWith plenty of hype around Belfast City Council’s -day celebratory lead-up to the main events of March , there will be no shortage of things to do on St Patrick’s Day itself.Try the city’s best-poured pints of Guinness at Bittles on Upper Church Lane or Whites Tavern, one of the oldest taverns in Belfast.Kelly’s Cellars, built in , is also one of the city’s longest-running pubs and will be full of trad music and great Guinness on the big day too. Another fundamentally Irish-themed pub to try is The Points, which will be hosting an all-day Dublin Road block party, to include  bands and DJs over six stages inside with free entry.Of course, this will have to wait until after you attend this year’s new look St Patrick’s Day parade by Beat Carnival — a colourful, carnival pageant of costume, music, dance, circus and theatrical performance.Watch as Patrick travels through the streets of Belfast with his giant hound, Spiorad-Spirit . He’ll be donning a giant cloak, elegantly patchwork-fashioned from expressions of people and groups throughout Belfast.All manner of iniduals and community organisations in the parade will celebrate their part in the future: ied and dferent yet strongly united by the instinct for moving forwards together — a cavalcade of carnival dancers, circus artists and musicians reminding us that We are all Patrick, we are all Belfast. The pageant parade will leave from City Hall at pm and will travel along Donegall Place, into High Street, Bridge Street, Waring Street and finish on Donegall Street close to Writers Square.Related title: taste test is taytos cheese and onion chocolate just the latest flavour of the month
story: Hype: Claire Williamson tries out Tayto’s new chocolateHype: Claire Williamson tries out Tayto’s new chocolate FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHype: Claire Williamson tries out Tayto’s new chocolateClaire WilliamsonTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailCrisps and chocolate — they are the go-to snack options of the nation.Separately they ide the masses – and it all comes down to inidual taste. Do you prefer a sweeter snack or do you opt for something more savoury Inidually they have their qualities and strong followings — and people can get pretty territorial over what brand they choose.So many dferent brands and flavours, dferent forms, textures and fillings.Personally, I prefer the more savoury snack and would usually opt for crisps.Tayto, in my opinion, are always very flavoursome.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Read MoreA sit-in fish supper could climb to £ in Belfast, says restaurant ownerSo, when I saw that Tayto had decided to combine their staple cheese and onion flavour crisps with chocolate — importantly, it notes, “with real crisp pieces” — it was definitely intriguing, an interesting concept. Expand" " class"c-lightbox-top-close icon-close" data-closeCloseHype: Claire Williamson tries out Tayto’s new chocolate FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueHype: Claire Williamson tries out Tayto’s new chocolateI mean, it would seem thatyou like chocolate and you like crisps, surely combining them is a win-win situation  Well, that all depends.It goes back to that age-old adage of just because you can, doesn’t mean you should.Because sometimes, in my opinion, when you are the master of one thing and you do it really well — in this case Tayto and their crisps — why risk it to try and become something  Don’t get me wrong, the packaging is eye-catching and distinguishable on the shelves.I was excited to try this after seeing it on social media and the buzz that had been created around it.But unfortunately, the taste was a little underwhelming. To be honest, I’m not sure what I expected, but I know it wasn’t what I got.Maybe I thought the crisp pieces would be much more prominent, maybe more of a crunch in the chocolate And I know I definitely thought the strong taste of Tayto cheese and onion would be more at the forefront.In short, to me it’s a little reminiscent of the popping candy chocolate. It’s chocolate with a little added something, but I don’t thinkyou were blind-folded you would know that it was crisp pieces.Personally, I couldn’t really taste the bits of Tayto crisps — unless the bar I got had a little less sprinkling of crisps pieces than others. Sadly, it just didn’t seem to live up to the hype.It’s a fun thing to try, but I’m not sure it’s something I’d be rushing out to buy again.Most ReadIncrease of ‘sexual shenanigans’ in Northern Ireland Credit: Liam McBurney PA WireSam McBrideTwitterEmailMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailStormont is on course to waste at least £m — and perhaps as much as £m — over the next  years due to its failure to find a way to spend Treasury funding made available to Northern Ireland for subsidising renewable heat.As revealed by the Belfastlast week, £m has already been wasted in this way and there is no sign of the Department for the Economy producing an alternative proposal for how it can spend the money.However, new figures show the vast scale of the waste aheadthe situation remains unaltered. In response to a Freedom of Information request from the Renewable Heat Association— which represents most RHI claimants — the department said that it was now on course to underspend by around £m. However, those figures only cover expenditure until , yet the GB RHI scheme — from whose budget Northern Ireland’s share of money for renewable heat is derived — has been extended and will not now close until .Based on that longer duration for the GB scheme, RHANI has calculated that Northern Ireland’s underspend may be closer to £m.Read MoreCriticism as Queen’s University Belfast ‘spends over £k’ on Amazon during pandemicThe hidden RHI scandal of how Stormont wasted £m in green energy subsidiesThe department said that it “will explore the potential to utilise any available [Treasury] funds in support of alternative or additional actions to decarbonise heat”. However, there is still no suggestion that this work has reached an advanced stage nor even that it will be possible because the Executive remains unable to decide how to handle existing RHI claimants.Those claimants were promised unalterable payments for  years but once the calamitous scale of the RHI overspend became apparent, Stormont abandoned that promise and retrospectively slashed their payments, meaning the actual overspend was £.m.That decision made them far less well rewarded than their counterparts in Great Britain or the Republic of Ireland, which recently launched its own version of RHI — putting Northern Irish businesses at a competitive disadvantage.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Sources within the DUP suggest that the party is split on how to handle the situation. Former leader Arlene Foster — the minister who set up the disastrous scheme but then said she was “accountable but not responsible” for the mess which followed — had endorsed a policy of throwing all RHI claimants out of the scheme, paying them a fraction of what they were originally promised as compensation. Sinn Fein has also endorsed this policy, but other DUP figures believe it is unfair to those claimants who entered the scheme in good faith, took on huge loans at the suggestion of its minister and government officials, and who did not abuse RHI.There is another factor which might explain the decision not to spend such a vast sum of money. The retrospective cuts to subsidies which had been guaranteed were immediately challenged in court by claimants. However, that process has moved tortoise-like over the last five years and has not yet gone to the Supreme Court. That case is just one of several RHI legal actions, the outcome of which the department cannot be certain.It may be that its decision not to launch a new green heat scheme is a way of hedging against the possibility that the original scheme is reinstated and it faces a vast compensation bill.Whatever the reason, it is having an increasingly stark impact. As oil and gas prices soar, renewables are among the cheapest alternatives — but have high up-front costs to install, which is why subsidies are in place where across the UK and Ireland.RHANI executive chairman Andrew Trimble said: “If civil servants had not removed  words from the national legislation on renewable heat when the NI legislation was implemented, then today we would have a strong, sustainable, environmentally friendly renewable heat sector. We would be contributing to our pathway to net zero and have a vastly reduced reliance on fossil fuels — with their polluting emissions reduced by %.”He said that Stormont could solve the problem by reinstating the missing  words — essentially replicating the GB scheme, with cost controls, something he said “could solve the political problems that Stormont and the department have created for themselves and for the people of Northern Ireland”.Mr Trimble highlighted that in , a Commons committee inquiry branded the department’s actions “a raw deal”, but the department had repeatedly failed title: taoiseach micheal martin tests positive for covid on st patricks day visit to washington ahead of planned meeting with joe biden
story: Taoiseach Micheal Martin has tested positive for Covid-.Mr Martin tested positive on a PCR test while on a trip in Washington DC ahead of St Patrick’s Day.The Taoiseach was due to meet US president Joe Biden on Thursday.Mr Martin tested positive earlier on Wednesday after initially testing negative after all members of the Irish delegation visiting Washington were tested and one member received a positive result.Mr Martin then was tested again and the result came back positive.It is likely that his plans to meet US president Joe Biden at the White House will be cancelled.The entire Irish delegation was antigen tested prior to a major gala event.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up Mr Martin was due to receive the Ireland Funds  International Leadership Award at a grand gala in Washington DC.Speaker Nancy Pelosi introduced the Taoiseach to receive the award but told the audience in her speech that he was unable to be here as he was on call.Ireland#s ambassador to the US Dan Mulhall accepted the award on his behalf and told the audience that Mr Martin had tested positive for Covid.It is understood that the Taoiseach is feeling well.US president Joe Biden addressed the gala event. He said that events had come full circle, as he first met Mr Martin when he was vice president and Mr Martin was Minister for Foreign Affairs in .Wednesday night was due to be the night that the two men meet for the first time before the official visit to the White House on Thursday.Mr Martin was supposed to be staying in Blair House on Wednesday night before meeting Mr Biden on Thursday.Officials accompanying Mr Martin in the US have said that the White House have told them that Joe Biden is not a close contact.It is believed that Mr Biden may still hold a virtual event with Mr Martin on Thursday.Mr Martin had arrived at the Ireland Funds gala event, and sources said they saw him wearing a face mask.It is understood the person who tested positive on an antigen test was a part of the Irish travelling delegation.Mr Martin has travelled to Versailles and London in recent days.Related topicsSt. Patrick#s DayMore On St. Patricks DaySt Patrick’s Day : Dublin parade in title: determined equestrian community taking horse boxes full of aid to poland
story: Boxed donations at a farm in Buxton to be transported to the Ukraine-Poland border in horse boxes  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueBoxed donations at a farm in Buxton to be transported to the Ukraine-Poland border in horse boxes By Gemma Bradley PAMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailA rider has raised more than £, with the help of the equestrian world to fund an aid-giving trip to Poland after seeing two dead Ukrainian children on the news.Stephen Barnes, , from Manchester, galvanised the equestrian community, which has donated money to support his trip to the Ukraine-Poland border with volunteers.The group will be delivering horse boxes full of aid such as blankets, clothes and first aid equipment while they also plan to bring back those with an eligible visa to enter the UK under the new Homes for Ukraine refugee scheme, or transport them to a place of refuge anywhere in Europe.Mr Barnes told the PA news agency he was motivated to begin title: gsk halts new clinical trials in russia but continues supply of medicines
story: Pharmaceutical giant GlaxoSmithKline is halting new trials in Russia but will continue to supply vital medicines  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":truePharmaceutical giant GlaxoSmithKline is halting new trials in Russia but will continue to supply vital medicines By Henry Saker-Clark, PA City ReporterMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailGlaxoSmithKlinehas said it will keep supplying essential medicines in Russia but will halt new clinical trials due to the invasion of Ukraine.The pharmaceutical giant confirmed it will not start clinical trials or enrol new patients in existing trials in Russia.It is the latest drug-maker to take such steps, although the healthcare sector has not pulled out of the region entirely as medicines and vaccines are considered necessary and are excluded from sanctions.GSK said it is prioritising supply of products essential for people’s health “while we can” and in compliance with sanctions.It added that any profits made from its operations in Russia will be used to support humanitarian relief efforts.See our latest on our position regarding the situation in Ukraine here. https:t.co zIHOqbbwl— GSKMarch , The company had already stopped advertising its products in Russia following the conflict.Annual group sales from Russia and Ukraine totalled around £ million in the previous financial year.GSK employs around  staff in Ukraine and said in its latest update that it is “doing everything we can to help them stay safe in very dficult conditions”.It added: “We are providing targeted humanitarian support through long-term NGO partners who have teams on the ground in Ukraine and neighbouring countries.“We’ll continue to respond as the situation evolves, guided by our humanitarian principles.”The firm has donated £. million to the Red Cross and Save the Children to provide food, water, first aid and medicine to people in Ukraine and refugees at the border. title: sadiq khan pushes for gross misconduct for officers in child q case
story: London Mayor Sadiq Khan  FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueLondon Mayor Sadiq Khan By Catherine Lough, PA Education CorrespondentMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailMayor of London Sadiq Khan has called for the officers who strip searched a black schoolgirl while on her period to be charged with gross misconduct after a report found racism had a role in their decision.A safeguarding report found that the “traumatic” search by politan Police officers at the end of  took place at the girl’s school without another adult present, and in the knowledge that she was menstruating.Incidents such as those experienced by Child Q, not only foster distrust in the Met but actively hamper any efforts to police by consent.London Mayor Sadiq KhanIt said that racism “was likely to have been an influencing factor” in the decision to carry out the search.After teachers called the police to the -year-old girl’s school, referred to as Child Q in the report, they conducted a strip search where her intimate body parts were exposed and she was made to take off her sanitary towel, according to the review.Mr Khan wrote to the Independent Office for Police Conduct on Wednesday to argue that the officers involved should be charged with gross misconduct rather than misconduct, because of the review’s finding that racism had a role in the decision to conduct the strip search.Mr Khan said he read the report with “dismay and disgust”, adding: “I understand that in line with statutory guidance, allegations of discrimination would normally be considered at the level of gross misconduct rather than misconduct.”The IOPC therefore recommends that the MPS take steps to ensure that their officers are not relying on the smell of cannabis alone when deciding to stop and search someone and use grounds based upon multiple objective factors.IOPC Action Plan, He said the sole reason for the search was the smell of cannabis, an issue which had previously been addressed by the IOPC, the College of Policing and City Hall’s Action Plan, published in November .The plan states: “The IOPC therefore recommends that the MPS [politan Police Service] take steps to ensure that their officers are not relying on the smell of cannabis alone when deciding to stop and search someone and use grounds based upon multiple objective factors.”In the review, Child Q said: “All the people that allowed this to happen need to be held responsible. I was held responsible for a smell… but I’m just a child.”Mr Khan wrote: “As Mayor, I have been clear that London’s police service must have the trust and confidence of the public they serve and incidents such as those experienced by Child Q, not only foster distrust in the Met but actively hamper any efforts to police by consent.”He said that Londoners “rightly expect their police service to act with the utmost integrity at all times”, and that where standards are not met, they need to have trust that those charged with investigating the police would “leave no stone unturned”.“This case has understandably caused widespread concern amongst the public and it is important that all allegations are thoroughly investigated, and that all relevant sources of information are taken into account,” he said. title: politicians from both sides of border tout for business as trade and tourism on agenda in us
story: Economy Minister Gordon Lyons. Credit: Liam McBurneyTaoiseach Micheal Martin. Credit: James Manning PAPA FacebookTwitterEmailWhatsapp,"onDemand":true,"lazyload":trueEconomy Minister Gordon Lyons. Credit: Liam McBurneyJonathan McCambridgeMarch   : AMFacebookTwitterEmailPoliticians from both sides of the border have been talking business in the US as a week of St Patrick’s celebrations continues.DUP Economy Minister Gordon Lyons signed an agreement with the State of Maryland, hailing Northern Ireland’s cyber security sector as world leading.In Washington, Micheal Martin said economic links between Ireland and the US were a “powerful two-way relationship”.Mr Lyons met with representatives from Maryland’s Department of Commerce and Department of Labor to strengthen ties under a joint cyber security memorandum of understanding, which aims to capitalise on the opportunities the sector offers to both economies.“Northern Ireland has a world class reputation for excellence in cyber security with specialist university research centres, innovative start-ups delivering global cyber security solutions and an impressive cluster of international cyber security investors,” he said.“This is why we are the number one international investment location for US cyber security firms, with Nisos and Agio just some of the US firms choosing to invest with us recently.”He also travelled to Washington, where he was due to hold a number of meetings, including one with US government energy officials to discuss opportunities around hydrogen.Daily Headlines  EveningNewsletterReceive today#s headlines directly to your inbox every morning and evening, with our free daily newsletter.Enter email addressThis field is requiredSign Up He was then due to attend The Ireland Fund’s th National Gala dinner to engage with influential business leaders.Meanwhile, the Taoiseach met with a number of Irish multinational companies based in the US.He emphasised the business and economic links between the two countries.He said: “Today we have been concentrating on the economic dimension of the Irish American relationship, which is a powerful two-way relationship. We met with a number of Irish multinational companies who have a very strong presence in the US.“American multinationals have a very strong presence in Ireland. Ireland equally has a very strong presence in the United States.“At a conservative estimate, Irish companies employ about , in the United States and bring a lot of expertise to areas like food, le sciences, technology.”Mr Martin also met with representatives from small and medium-sized companies which are led by women and discussed better channels of mobility of workers between the US and Ireland.The Taoiseach later presented Science Foundation Ireland awards to John and Patrick Collison, founders of financial services firm Stripe.Later he was due to appear at the th anniversary of the gala dinner, with President Joe Biden expected to make an appearance.The event is expected to raise over  million for charitable causes across Ireland.On Tuesday night Mr Martin declared Ireland’s tourism industry once again ready to welcome visitors from across the world after Covid.Mr Martin was speaking at a reception hosted by Tourism Ireland at the Kennedy Centre in Washington before watching a special th anniversary performance of Riverdance.He added: “The beauty, the history and the culture of our island has long made tourism one of the most important parts of not just our economy, but also our society.“We have greatly missed welcoming American and other visitors to Ireland.“Before Covid- in , we welcomed over  million overseas visitors to the island of Ireland.“Now is the moment for us to again open our arms, to welcome visitors and to show you the extraordinary sights and experiences of a unique island.” Earlier, Mr Lyons attended a business breakfast in New York organised by Tourism Ireland, where he took the opportunity to promote Northern Ireland as a holiday destination to US travel industry professionals.The Taoiseach also mentioned locations north of the border as he promoted the island as a destination for visitors. “Tourism Ireland’s Green Button campaign is continuing throughout this year. The campaign champions our strengths and iconic locations, from the Clfs of Moher and the Wild Atlantic Way, to Titanic Belfast and the Giant’s Causeway in Northern Ireland,” he said.“Ireland is a wonderful place for a holiday.“The warmth and hospitality of the people still stands, our scenery is stunning.“Ireland stands ready to welcome back our friends from the United States.”Related title: £15m investment for rural development
story: OVER poundm has been invested in a number of projects across the Newry, Mourne and Down Council area with funding provided under the Rural Development Programme.The cash was administered by the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership with the Leader Programmersquos village renewal money supporting  projects, including the development or refurbishment of  community facilities, benefiting over , people.Stormont rural affairs minister Edwin Poots attended a recent event at Killeavy Castle in Newry to celebrate the success in delivering his Departmentrsquos programme which also created  new jobs.He congratulated members of the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Rural Development Partnership for their work in delivering the programme, supporting village renewal and improving infrastructure.The minister also referenced his recent statement to the Assembly regarding Northern Irelandrsquos first ever rural policy framework.ldquoI want to create a new programme going forward that will be completely tailored to our own unique circumstances in Northern Ireland, he explained.ldquoThe framework will see a new rural business and community investment programme that will cover the next seven years and will support my Departmentrsquos vision of putting sustainability at the heart of a living, working, active landscape valued by everyone.In addition, Mr Poots said the new framework will also demonstrate his Departmentrsquos ongoing commitment to ensuring that rural communities flourish and prosper through continued support and investment in initiatives that will make a tangible dference to those living and working in rural areas.Cllr Roisin Mulgrew, chairwoman of the Mourne, Gullion and Lecale Partnership, said the delivery of the programme has brought ldquosignicant benefits to the rural dwellers of Newry, Mourne and Down and is testament to the dedication of the Local Action Group.She added: ldquoThe knowledge of the members has ensured projects of high quality have been supported, which have positively impacted on the lives of the rural dwellers.Council chairwoman, Cathy Mason, said the organisation, in partnership with the Local Action Group and Department of Agriculture, Environment and Rural Affairs, has been extremely successful in the delivery of the Leader programme.ldquoThe positive impacts have ensured a strong rural economy, providing dwellers with access to high quality community facilities, towns and villages they can be proud to call home, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Ambitious plans for Camino style walk  in Down District
story: AMBITIOUS plans for a major walking trail which passes through Down District have received a pound, boost.A key component of the planned Columban Way is to develop ldquopilgrimage walking such as that found at Spainrsquos Camino de Santiago and at many other trails across Europe, with the trail highlighting Northern Irelandrsquos ancient heritage, including major Neolithic and early Christian sites along the way.It has been confirmed that a pound, grant has made available by the David Cross Foundation to produce a business case with costings to identy and develop the Columban Way from Dundrum to the Saint Patrickrsquos Centre in Downpatrick and from there to Comber by repurposing and upgrading sections of the former Ulster Way which was abandoned in the s.St Columbanus was one of the best-known of hundreds of Irish monks following in the footsteps of Saint Patrick in bringing Christianity, literacy and learning to Central and Northern Europe in the sixth century.Downpatrick councillor Cadogan Enright mdash who is an enthusiastic supporter of the new trail mdash said ii took St Columbanus  years to complete the journey from Bangor to Bobbio in Italy and he travelled more than , miles, mostly on foot.He is leading the local aspect of the project alongside Charlie Reid from Bangor, with both writing extensively on walks around Ireland and are committee members of Friends of Columbanus. They are supported by Duane Fitzsimons, from Ardglass, who is a walking trails expert.ldquoThe Columban Way forms part of the wider European lsquoVia Columbanirsquo heritage trail supported and promoted by the Council of Europe. It traces the route from Mount Leinster to Bangor through eight European countries to Bobbio in Italy, explained Cllr Enright.ldquoIt is instructive to see how rapidly other countries have rolled out sections of the trail since  and the th anniversary of Columbanus. Switzerland, Italy, France, Germany and the Low Countries have demonstrated the ability to deliver that we can learn from locally.Cllr Enright praised the support of Ards and North Down Council which has already delivered  miles of walk as far south as Comber.ldquoThis -mile section of trail is designed to encourage more people to learn about the history of North Down and Ards, including the impact the area had in a European context through the links with Columbanus, he explained.ldquoOur big challenge will be to engage with Newry Mourne and Down Council to deal with their huge gaps in the Saint Patrickrsquos and Ulster Ways. These should link Downpatrick to Dundrum and Killyleagh, but still have not yet done so..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch Women win yet again
story: BALLYNAHINCH continue their pursuit of a domestic double when they travel to Armagh on Saturday in the quarter-finals of the Senior Cup.Ballynahinch Women followed up their win over leaders Carrickfergus with a hard fought - victory over derby rivals Lisburn.The teams shared six tries with a lone Jane Patton conversion proving the dference between the sides on a dficult surface.Veteran centre Rachel Morton weighed in with two tries and Avril Sherlock was the other try scorer.Coach Sara Simms and her team will be pleased with the rate of improvement shown and will hope to keep pushing up the table during the final part of the season.The seconds continue to blood young players during their Second XV League campaign and had another emphatic home win on Saturday.Armagh were on the end of a five tries to one defeat and coach Davy Harris will have been pleased with the response his team have shown since their Townsrsquo Cup defeat at the end of February.James Martin, Matthew Cooper, Ben McMullan, Cameron McGaughey and Harry McCormick were the try scorers.Injuries and call-ups to the first XV squad have had an impact and there will be opportunities for young players to stake a claim for a place in the senior squad next season over the next few weeks.Marty OrsquoNeillrsquos fourth XV continued their red-hot  form with an excellent - victory over Harlequins thirds.They have a % record in their league section and face a crucial three-week period with home and away fixtures against nearest rivals Academy either side of a Forster Plate semi-final against Donegal Town.A fth XV squad with an average age of  travelled to Banbridge on Friday night and came home with a superb - victory.Tiernan Keating, Conor Spence and Sam Forbes made their senior debuts and  players had appeared at some stage this season for the club Academy side.They have three consecutive home games coming up, including a home semi-final in the McCambley Cup against Ballymena fourths.Youth training continues at pm on Monday nights.
